Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black with reserved band at rim; lotus flower and palmette in added red and white; exterior: at rim, broken maeander pattern between pairs of bands; below, painted decoration consisting of horse and rider to left (part of horse's neck, mane and rein in yellowish brown; head, neck, shoulder, arm and hand holding rein of bearded rider, with white fillet in red hair).
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in the Grand Style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy. Though there is no evidence for filling ornament on this sherd, nor any attempt at perspective, the depiction of male figures in this group is done in outline as the male figure appears here. In later Grand Style vases, male figures are depicted with coloured flesh.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 110, p. 272, no. 706, pl. I, pl. 93)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 140, no. 799, pl. 96)
